frameDefinitions: This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.

A Manner describes general or specific characteristics of an event in one of three ways:  First, it can refer to how a Comparison_event transpires, absent the influence of an entity (e.g. 'the way you talk').
A Cognizer makes a Decision, which may be about an entity or a course of action.
A Captor ends the captivity or inhibition of the motion of a Theme from the Location_of_confinement.
A Speaker addresses a Proposal made by an Interlocutor, either agreeing to it or rejecting it.
A Speaker uses language to affirm or deny the truth of a Message to some Addressee.
frameExamples: Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
He completed the task in a fervent <t>manner</t>.
They <t>released</t> me from prison on New Year's Day.
They were <t>rebuffed</t> again in the larger city of Provo. CNI
She <t>affirmed</t> her loyalty to the cause.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.

The <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is the principal event being characteriszed by the <fen>Manner</fen>. The <fen>Manner</fen> of this <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is often used in comparison with the <fen>Foreground_event</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is associated with or directly responsible for the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
The description of the <fen>Comparison_event</fen> or <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
A description of the <fen>Manner</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> conducts or engages in the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen> that is being described.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> decides on a course of action.
<fen>Decision</fen> identifies the entity or course of action upon which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> decides.
The time or time period over which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the decision.
The place where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the decision.
The <fen>Captor</fen> is the individual who ends the confinement or captivity of the <fen>Theme</fen>. The release of the <fen>Theme</fen> is in accord with the plans of the <fen>Captor</fen>.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the person or object in motion released by the <fen>Captor</fen>.
The location to which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s motion was formerly inhibited.
The <fen>Time</fen> identifies when the <fen>Captor</fen> release the <fen>Theme</fen> .
The location where the <fen>Theme</fen> ceases to be confined.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who communicates the reply or response.

This is the person who made the <fen>Proposal</fen> to the <fen>Speaker</fen> and to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates  their response. This frame element stands in for the <fen>Proposal</fen> and is only licensed when the <fen>Proposal</fen>  can be understood from the context.
The <fen>Proposal</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity affirming or denying the truth of the <fen>Message</fen> (this can be spoken or written). It is normally expressed as the External Argument of the predicative uses of the target word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> identifies the content whose truth the <fen>Speaker</fen> is affirming or denying. It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is rarely mentioned in constructions with verbal targets, and is much more common with nominal targets, where it is usually expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'of' or about'.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is affirmed or denied.
<fen>Place</fen> specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> is affirmed or denied.
listRoleExamples: Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
The State Cabinet <fex>today</fex> decided to file an appeal in the Supreme Court seeking an extension of six months for implementation of its judgment
<fex>At the first</fex> crossroad we decided to wait.
She petitioned unsuccessfully for their release <fex>from Chateau D'If</fex>.
'Aren't you going to release us <fex>here</fex>?' she asked.
<fex>Iran</fex> on Saturday rejected Europe's proposal for ending the standoff over Tehran's nuclear program.

But senior SLN officials had rebuffed <fex>the man who is ever so willing to please
the guerrillas</fex>.
Dr. Carolyn Herrington has accepted <fex>our offer to become Dean of the College of Education</fex> .
This must make <fex>yesterday's</fex> Taliban rebuff all the more wounding.
Legislation that would have required smaller school districts to share administrators has been rebuffed repeatedly <fex>in the Oklahoma House of Representatives</fex>.
No one believed <fex>Evelyn</fex>'s affirmation that she could speak to ghosts.
They refute the criticisms <fex>that they are only interested in power and money</fex>.
